Description: compare and contrast prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: investigate and explain cellular processes, including homeostasis, energy conversions, transport of molecules, and synthesis of new molecules.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: compare the structures of viruses to cells, describe viral reproduction, and describe the role of viruses in causing diseases such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and influenza.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the stages of the cell cycle, including deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) replication and mitosis, and the importance of the cell cycle to the growth of organisms.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: examine specialized cells, including roots, stems, and leaves of plants; and animal cells such as blood, muscle, and epithelium.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the roles of DNA, ribonucleic acid (RNA), and environmental factors in cell differentiation.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: recognize that disruptions of the cell cycle lead to diseases such as cancer.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify components of DNA, and describe how information for specifying the traits of an organism is carried in the DNA.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: recognize that components that make up the genetic code are common to all organisms.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the purpose and process of transcription and translation using models of DNA and RNA.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: recognize that gene expression is a regulated process.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify and illustrate changes in DNA and evaluate the significance of these changes.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: predict possible outcomes of various genetic combinations such as monohybrid crosses, dihybrid crosses and non-Mendelian inheritance.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: recognize the significance of meiosis to sexual reproduction.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe how techniques such as DNA fingerprinting, genetic modifications, and chromosomal analysis are used to study the genomes of organisms.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze and evaluate how evidence of common ancestry among groups is provided by the fossil record, biogeography, and homologies, including anatomical, molecular, and developmental.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze and evaluate scientific explanations concerning any data of sudden appearance, stasis, and sequential nature of groups in the fossil record.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze and evaluate how natural selection produces change in populations, not individuals.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze and evaluate how the elements of natural selection, including inherited variation, the potential of a population to produce more offspring than can survive, and a finite supply of environmental resources, result in differential reproductive success.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze and evaluate the relationship of natural selection to adaptation and to the development of diversity in and among species.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze and evaluate the effects of other evolutionary mechanisms, including genetic drift, gene flow, mutation, and recombination.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze and evaluate scientific explanations concerning the complexity of the cell.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: define taxonomy and recognize the importance of a standardized taxonomic system to the scientific community.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: categorize organisms using a hierarchical classification system based on similarities and differences shared among groups.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: compare characteristics of taxonomic groups, including archaea, bacteria, protists, fungi, plants, and animals.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: compare the structures and functions of different types of biomolecules, including carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: compare the reactants and products of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in terms of energy and matter.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify and investigate the role of enzymes.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze and evaluate the evidence regarding formation of simple organic molecules and their organization into long complex molecules having information such as the DNA molecule for self-replicating life.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations, including the appropriate use of safety showers, eyewash fountains, safety goggles, and fire extinguishers.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: know specific hazards of chemical substances such as flammability, corrosiveness, and radioactivity as summarized on the Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS).
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the unique role of water in chemical and biological systems.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: develop and use general rules regarding solubility through investigations with aqueous solutions.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: calculate the concentration of solutions in units of molarity.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use molarity to calculate the dilutions of solutions.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: distinguish between types of solutions such as electrolytes and nonelectrolytes and unsaturated, saturated, and supersaturated solutions.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: investigate factors that influence solubilities and rates of dissolution such as temperature, agitation, and surface area.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: define acids and bases and distinguish between Arrhenius and Bronsted-Lowry definitions and predict products in acid base reactions that form water.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: understand and differentiate among acid-base reactions, precipitation reactions, and oxidation-reduction reactions.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: define pH and use the hydrogen or hydroxide ion concentrations to calculate the pH of a solution.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: distinguish between degrees of dissociation for strong and weak acids and bases.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: understand energy and its forms, including kinetic, potential, chemical, and thermal energies.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: understand the law of conservation of energy and the processes of heat transfer.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use thermochemical equations to calculate energy changes that occur in chemical reactions and classify reactions as exothermic or endothermic.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: perform calculations involving heat, mass, temperature change, and specific heat.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use calorimetry to calculate the heat of a chemical process.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the characteristics of alpha, beta, and gamma radiation.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe radioactive decay process in terms of balanced nuclear equations.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: compare fission and fusion reactions.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in subsection (b)(2) of this section.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: know that scientific hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power which have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: plan and implement investigative procedures, including asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting equipment and technology, including graphing calculators, computers and probes, sufficient scientific glassware such as beakers, Erlenmeyer flasks, pipettes, graduated cylinders, volumetric flasks, safety goggles, and burettes, electronic balances, and an adequate supply of consumable chemicals.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: collect data and make measurements with accuracy and precision.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: express and manipulate chemical quantities using scientific conventions and mathematical procedures, including dimensional analysis, scientific notation, and significant figures.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: organize, analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphs, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: in all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: evaluate the impact of research on scientific thought, society, and the environment.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the connection between chemistry and future careers.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: research and describe the history of chemistry and contributions of scientists.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: differentiate between physical and chemical changes and properties.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify extensive and intensive properties.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: compare solids, liquids, and gases in terms of compressibility, structure, shape, and volume.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: classify matter as pure substances or mixtures through investigation of their properties.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the use of chemical and physical properties in the historical development of the Periodic Table.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use the Periodic Table to identify and explain the properties of chemical families, including alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, halogens, noble gases, and transition metals.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use the Periodic Table to identify and explain periodic trends, including atomic and ionic radii, electronegativity, and ionization energy.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: understand the experimental design and conclusions used in the development of modern atomic theory, including Dalton's Postulates, Thomson's discovery of electron properties, Rutherford's nuclear atom, and Bohr's nuclear atom.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: understand the electromagnetic spectrum and the mathematical relationships between energy, frequency, and wavelength of light.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: calculate the wavelength, frequency, and energy of light using Planck's constant and the speed of light.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use isotopic composition to calculate average atomic mass of an element.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: express the arrangement of electrons in atoms through electron configurations and Lewis valence electron dot structures.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: name ionic compounds containing main group or transition metals, covalent compounds, acids, and bases, using International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature rules.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the nature of metallic bonding and apply the theory to explain metallic properties such as thermal and electrical conductivity, malleability, and ductility.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: predict molecular structure for molecules with linear, trigonal planar, or tetrahedral electron pair geometries using Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) theory.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: define and use the concept of a mole.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use the mole concept to calculate the number of atoms, ions, or molecules in a sample of material.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: calculate percent composition and empirical and molecular formulas.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use the law of conservation of mass to write and balance chemical equations.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: perform stoichiometric calculations, including determination of mass relationships between reactants and products, calculation of limiting reagents, and percent yield.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe and calculate the relations between volume, pressure, number of moles, and temperature for an ideal gas as described by Boyle's law, Charles' law, Avogadro's law, Dalton's law of partial pressure, and the ideal gas law.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: perform stoichiometric calculations, including determination of mass and volume relationships between reactants and products for reactions involving gases.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the postulates of kinetic molecular theory.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations, including appropriate first aid responses to accidents that could occur in the field such as insect stings, animal bites, overheating, sprains, and breaks.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

Description: analyze and predict the effects of non-renewable resource depletion.

Description: describe and calculate how the magnitude of the gravitational force between two objects depends on their masses and the distance between their centers.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe and calculate how the magnitude of the electrical force between two objects depends on their charges and the distance between them.

Description: characterize materials as conductors or insulators based on their electrical properties.

Description: design, construct, and calculate in terms of current through, potential difference across, resistance of, and power used by electric circuit elements connected in both series and parallel combinations.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: investigate and describe the relationship between electric and magnetic fields in applications such as generators, motors, and transformers.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe evidence for and effects of the strong and weak nuclear forces in nature.

Description: investigate and calculate quantities using the work-energy theorem in various situations.

Description: demonstrate and apply the laws of conservation of energy and conservation of momentum in one dimension.

Description: analyze and explain everyday examples that illustrate the laws of thermodynamics, including the law of conservation of energy and the law of entropy.

Description: describe and predict image formation as a consequence of reflection from a plane mirror and refraction through a thin convex lens.

Description: describe the role of wave characteristics and behaviors in medical and industrial applications.

Description: describe the photoelectric effect and the dual nature of light.

Description: give examples of applications of atomic and nuclear phenomena such as radiation therapy, diagnostic imaging, and nuclear power and examples of applications of quantum phenomena such as digital cameras.

Description: make wise choices in the use and conservation of resources and the disposal or recycling of materials.

Description: investigate and identify the law of conservation of mass.

Description: describe types of nuclear reactions such as fission and fusion and their roles in applications such as medicine and energy production.

Description: research and describe the environmental and economic impact of the end-products of chemical reactions.

Description: relate the structure of water to its function as the universal solvent.

Description: demonstrate how factors such as particle size, influence the rate of dissolving.

Description: compare variations, tolerances, and adaptations of plants and animals in different biomes.

Description: identify and illustrate that long-term survival of species is dependent on a resource base that may be limited.

Description: investigate and explain the interactions in an ecosystem including food chains, food webs, and food pyramids.

Description: evaluate the significance of structural and physiological adaptations of plants to their environments.

Description: survey and identify methods of reproduction, growth, and development of various types of plants.

Description: evaluate promotional claims that relate to biological issues such as product labeling and advertisements.

Description: describe the connection between biology and future careers.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: evaluate models according to their adequacy in representing biological objects or events.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: research and describe the history of biology and contributions of scientists.

Description: identify the parts of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.

Description: investigate and identify cellular processes including homeostasis, permeability, energy production, transportation of molecules, disposal of wastes, function of cellular parts, and synthesis of new molecules.

Description: identify and illustrate how changes in DNA cause mutations and evaluate the significance of these changes.

Description: Observable physical properties can be used to classify materials.  These physical properties may include solubility, mass, magnetism, and electrical conductivity.  Tools such as graduated cylinders, balances, rulers, magnifiers, simple circuits, and magnets are used to study the physical properties. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Heating and cooling of materials may produce changes in the state of solids, liquids and gases. (Level:  Important)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Most materials are physical mixtures.  Physical mixtures can be composed of different kinds of materials, each having distinct physical properties.  These physical property differences can be used to separate, sort, and group the materials of the mixture. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Mixtures can consist of different combinations of solids and/or liquids.  The characteristics of these resulting mixtures depend on the relative amounts and properties of the components. (Level:  Essential
Physical properties can be used to separate mixtures through techniques such as filtration and evaporation. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: When a solid is dissolved in a liquid, a solution is formed that can be separated through the process of evaporation. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: The mass of an object remains unchanged when broken into parts.  The sum of the parts equals the whole. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: The energy of a moving object depends on its speed.  Faster moving objects have more energy than slower moving objects. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Energy can be stored in an elastic material when it is stretched. (Level:  Important)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Force is any push or pull exerted by one object on another.  Some forces (e.g., magnetic forces and gravity) can make things move without touching them. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: The speeds of two or more objects can be compared (i.e., faster, slower) by measuring the distance traveled in a given unit of time, or by measuring the time needed to travel a fixed distance. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: A force must be applied to change the speed of a moving object or change its direction of motion.  Larger forces will create greater changes in an object’s speed in a given unit of time. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Pushing and pulling forces can be used to transfer energy from one object to another. (Level:  Important)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Water exists in three states (solid, liquid and gas) that are dependent upon the surrounding temperature. (Level:  Important)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Organisms can be grouped based on similarities and differences in their structures and functions.  These may include characteristics such as appendages, roots and leaves of plants, or the presence or lack of a backbone. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Plants need the Sun’s energy to grow and survive. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Animals need food to provide materials and energy for life which they derive directly or indirectly from plants. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: An organism displays behaviors in response to internal cues, such as hunger, and external cues, such as light, temperature, or interaction with living things. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: There are similarities and differences in how organisms respond to internal and external cues.  These behaviors may include strategies for acquiring food, building shelters, or evading predators. (Level:  Important)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Short term and long term studies are used to determine the effects of environmental changes (natural and man-made) on the health of the organisms within that environment. (Level:  Important)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Physical characteristics are passed on from parent to offspring.  Organisms with two parents inherit characteristics of both. (Level:  Important)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Most plants go through a life cycle of germination, growth, development, reproduction, and death. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Reproduction is a characteristic of all living systems and is essential to the continuation of every species. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Some organisms reproduce asexually involving one parent.  Asexual reproduction results in offspring that are genetically identical to the parent organism (clones).  This process is advantageous in maintaining the genetic make-up of organisms that are successful in a specific environment. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Some organisms reproduce sexually involving two parents. Sexual reproduction results in offspring that have greater genetic diversity than those resulting from asexual reproduction. One-half of the offspring’s genetic information comes from the “male” parent and one-half comes from the “female” parent. These genetic differences help to ensure the survival of offspring in varied environments. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Chromosomes are found in the nucleus of the cell and contain genes that are made of DNA.  Inherited traits of individuals are controlled by genes. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Chromosomes can be arranged in pairs (one-half of each pair from each parent). These pairs are approximately the same size and shape, and have similar sequences of genes. Humans have 23 pairs (46) of chromosomes.  Other organisms may have different numbers of chromosomes. (Level:  Important)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: A dominant trait will be expressed if the organism is heterozygous or homozygous for the trait.  A recessive trait will only be expressed if the organism is homozygous for the trait. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Mendelian genetics can be used to predict genotypes and phenotypes of offspring resulting from sexual reproduction. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Natural selection is the process by which some individuals with certain traits are more likely to survive and produce greater numbers of offspring than other organisms of the same species.  Competition for resources and mates and conditions in the environment can affect which individuals survive, reproduce and pass their traits on to future generations. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Selective breeding is used to cultivate plants and domesticated animals with desirable traits. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Knowledge gained from research in genetics is being applied to areas of human health.  Geneticists and genetic counselors may use pedigrees and Punnett squares to help predict the possibility of genetic disorders in future generations. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: All living organisms interact with the living and nonliving parts of their surroundings to meet their needs for survival.  These interactions lead to a constant exchange of matter. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Adaptations in organisms enable them to live and reproduce in certain environments.  Those organisms that are best suited for a particular environment have adaptations that allow them to compete for available resources and cope with the physical conditions of their immediate surroundings. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: In order to survive, populations within an ecosystem require a balance of resources. (Level:  Important)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Earth’s ecosystems are interconnected by biological, chemical, and physical processes.  Changes in one ecosystem may have local and/or global consequences. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Plants need energy from the Sun, water and nutrients for growth and survival. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Animals eat plants or other animals that have eaten plants.  Animals obtain energy and materials for body repair and growth from food. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Dead plants and animals are broken down by decomposers. (Level:  Essential)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Students will demonstrate how individual economic choices are made within the context of a market economy in which markets influence the production and distribution of goods and services. (Essential for Grades 10 and 11)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Students will develop an understanding of how economies function as a whole, including the causes and effects of inflation, unemployment, business cycles, and monetary and fiscal policies. (Essential for Grades 10 and 11)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Students will analyze the wide range of opportunities and consequences resulting from the current transitions from command to market economies in many countries. (Essential for Grade 10)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: Students will analyze and interpret the influence of the distribution of the world's resources, political stability, national efforts to encourage or discourage trade, and the flow of investment on patterns of international trade. (Essential for Grade 10)
ContentStandard.Title: Content Standard

Description: explain the significance of various community, state, and national celebrations such as Veterans Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, and Thanksgiving.

Description: identify and explain the significance of various community, state, and national landmarks such as monuments and government buildings.

Description: obtain information about a topic using a variety of valid visual sources such as pictures, maps, electronic sources, literature, reference sources, and artifacts.

Description: explain how selected customs, symbols, and celebrations reflect an American love of individualism, inventiveness, and freedom.

Description: identify selected stories, poems, statues, paintings, and other examples of the local cultural heritage.

Description: describe how science and technology have changed communication, transportation, and recreation.

Description: explain how science and technology have changed the ways in which people meet basic needs.

Description: obtain information about a topic using a variety of oral sources such as conversations, interviews, and music.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: obtain information about a topic using a variety of visual sources such as pictures, graphics, television, maps, computer software, literature, reference sources, and artifacts.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use various parts of a source, including the table of contents, glossary, and index, as well as keyword computer searches, to locate information.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: sequence and categorize information.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: interpret oral, visual, and print material by identifying the main idea, predicting, and comparing and contrasting.

Description: express ideas orally based on knowledge and experiences.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: create written and visual material such as stories, poems, maps, and graphic organizers to express ideas.

Description: use a decision-making process to identify a situation that requires a decision, gather information, identify options, predict consequences, and take action to implement a decision.

Description: describe and measure calendar time by days, weeks, months, and years.

Description: name several sources of information about a given period or event.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: compare various interpretations of the same time period using evidence such as photographs and interviews.

Description: identify contributions of historical figures such as Henrietta King and Thurgood Marshall who have influenced the community, state, and nation.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify historic figures such as Amelia Earhart and Robert Fulton who have exhibited a love of individualism and inventiveness.

Description: compare information from different sources about places and regions.

Description: explain how people depend on the physical environment and its natural resources to satisfy their basic needs.

Description: identify ways people can conserve and replenish natural resources.

Description: explain how work provides income to purchase goods and services.

Description: explain the choices people in the U.S. free enterprise system can make about earning, spending, and saving money, and where to live and work.

Description: explain the contributions of the Founding Fathers such as Benjamin Rush, John Hancock, John Jay, John Witherspoon, John Peter Muhlenberg, Charles Carroll, and Jonathan Trumbull Sr.

Description: describe Ronald Reagan's leadership in domestic and international policies, including Reaganomics and Peace Through Strength.

Description: compare the impact of energy on the American way of life over time.

Description: describe significant societal issues of this time period.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe U.S. involvement in world affairs, including the end of the Cold War, the Persian Gulf War, the Balkans Crisis, 9/11, and the global War on Terror.

Description: evaluate efforts by global organizations to undermine U.S. sovereignty through the use of treaties.

Description: analyze the impact of third parties on presidential elections.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: discuss the historical significance of the 2008 presidential election.

Description: discuss the solvency of long-term entitlement programs such as Social Security and Medicare.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze the impact of physical and human geographic factors on the settlement of the Great Plains, the Klondike Gold Rush, the Panama Canal, the Dust Bowl, and the levee failure in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina.

Description: analyze the causes and effects of changing demographic patterns resulting from legal and illegal immigration to the United States.

Description: identify the effects of population growth and distribution on the physical environment.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: understand the effects of governmental actions on individuals, industries, and communities, including the impact on Fifth Amendment property rights.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe how the economic impact of the Transcontinental Railroad and the Homestead Act contributed to the close of the frontier in the late 19th century.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the changing relationship between the federal government and private business, including the costs and benefits of laissez-faire, anti-trust acts, the Interstate Commerce Act, and the Pure Food and Drug Act.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain how foreign policies affected economic issues such as the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, the Open Door Policy, Dollar Diplomacy, and immigration quotas.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the economic effects of international military conflicts, including the Spanish-American War and World War I, on the United States.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the emergence of monetary policy in the United States, including the Federal Reserve Act of 1913 and the shifting trend from a gold standard to fiat money.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze causes of economic growth and prosperity in the 1920s, including Warren Harding's Return to Normalcy, reduced taxes, and increased production efficiencies.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify the causes of the Great Depression, including the impact of tariffs on world trade, stock market speculation, bank failures, and the monetary policy of the Federal Reserve System.

Description: analyze the effects of the Great Depression on the U.S. economy and society such as widespread unemployment and deportation and repatriation of people of European and Mexican heritage and others.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: compare the New Deal policies and its opponents' approaches to resolving the economic effects of the Great Depression.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe how various New Deal agencies and programs, including the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Social Security Administration, continue to affect the lives of U.S. citizens.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the economic effects of World War II on the home front such as the end of the Great Depression, rationing, and increased opportunity for women and minority employment.

Description: identify the causes of prosperity in the 1950s, including the Baby Boom and the impact of the GI Bill (Servicemen's Readjustment Act of 1944), and the effects of prosperity in the 1950s such as increased consumption and the growth of agriculture and business.

Description: describe the economic impact of defense spending on the business cycle and education priorities from 1945 to the 1990s.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify actions of government and the private sector such as the Great Society, affirmative action, and Title IX to create economic opportunities for citizens and analyze the unintended consequences of each.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the dynamic relationship between U.S. international trade policies and the U.S. free enterprise system such as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) oil embargo, the General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade (GATT), and the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: discuss the role of American entrepreneurs such as Bill Gates, Sam Walton, Estï¿½e Lauder, Robert Johnson, Lionel Sosa, and millions of small business entrepreneurs who achieved the American dream.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify the impact of international events, multinational corporations, government policies, and individuals on the 21st century economy.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: evaluate the impact of New Deal legislation on the historical roles of state and federal government.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain constitutional issues raised by federal government policy changes during times of significant events, including World War I, the Great Depression, World War II, the 1960s, and 9/11.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the effects of political scandals, including Teapot Dome, Watergate, and Bill Clinton's impeachment, on the views of U.S. citizens concerning trust in the federal government and its leaders.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: discuss the role of contemporary government legislation in the private and public sectors such as the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, USA PATRIOT Act of 2001, and the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: evaluate the pros and cons of U.S. participation in international organizations and treaties.

Description: identify the major characteristics that define an historical era.

Description: identify the major eras in U.S. history from 1877 to the present and describe their defining characteristics.

Description: apply absolute and relative chronology through the sequencing of significant individuals, events, and time periods.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the significance of the following years as turning points: 1898 (Spanish-American War), 1914-1918 (World War I), 1929 (the Great Depression begins), 1939-1945 (World War II), 1957 (Sputnik launch ignites U.S.-Soviet space race), 1968-1969 (Martin Luther King Jr. assassination and U.S. lands on the moon), 1991 (Cold War ends), 2001 (terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and the Pentagon), and 2008 (election of first black president, Barack Obama).
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the impact of events such as the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution and the War Powers Act on the relationship between the legislative and executive branches of government.

Description: evaluate the impact of relationships among the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of government, including Franklin D. Roosevelt's attempt to increase the number of U.S. Supreme Court justices and the presidential election of 2000.

Description: discuss historical reasons why the constitution has been amended.

Description: evaluate constitutional change in terms of strict construction versus judicial interpretation.

Description: discuss Alexis de Tocqueville's five values crucial to America's success as a constitutional republic: liberty, egalitarianism, individualism, populism, and laissez-faire.

Description: describe how the American values identified by Alexis de Tocqueville are different and unique from those of other nations.

Description: describe U.S. citizens as people from numerous places throughout the world who hold a common bond in standing for certain self-evident truths.

Description: explain how participation in the democratic process reflects our national ethos, patriotism, and civic responsibility as well as our progress to build a "more perfect union."

Description: describe qualities of effective leadership.

Description: evaluate the contributions of significant political and social leaders in the United States such as Andrew Carnegie, Thurgood Marshall, Billy Graham, Barry Goldwater, Sandra Day O'Connor, and Hillary Clinton.

Description: identify the impact of popular American culture on the rest of the world over time.

Description: discuss the Americanization movement to assimilate immigrants and American Indians into American culture.

Description: explain how the contributions of people of various racial, ethnic, gender, and religious groups shape American culture.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify the political, social, and economic contributions of women such as Frances Willard, Jane Addams, Eleanor Roosevelt, Dolores Huerta, Sonia Sotomayor, and Oprah Winfrey to American society.

Description: discuss the meaning and historical significance of the mottos "E Pluribus Unum" and "In God We Trust".

Description: explain the effects of scientific discoveries and technological innovations such as electric power, telephone and satellite communications, petroleum-based products, steel production, and computers on the economic development of the United States.

Description: explain how specific needs result in scientific discoveries and technological innovations in agriculture, the military, and medicine, including vaccines.

Description: analyze how scientific discoveries, technological innovations, and the application of these by the free enterprise system, including those in transportation and communication, improve the standard of living in the United States.

Description: explain how space technology and exploration improve the quality of life.

Description: understand how the free enterprise system drives technological innovation and its application in the marketplace such as cell phones, inexpensive personal computers, and global positioning products.

Description: use a variety of both primary and secondary valid sources to acquire information and to analyze and answer historical questions.

Description: analyze information by sequencing, categorizing, identifying cause-and-effect relationships, comparing and contrasting, finding the main idea, summarizing, making generalizations, making predictions, drawing inferences, and drawing conclusions.

Description: use the process of historical inquiry to research, interpret, and use multiple types of sources of evidence.

Description: evaluate the validity of a source based on language, corroboration with other sources, and information about the author, including points of view, frames of reference, and historical context.

Description: identify bias in written, oral, and visual material.

Description: identify and support with historical evidence a point of view on a social studies issue or event.

Description: use appropriate skills to analyze and interpret social studies information such as maps, graphs, presentations, speeches, lectures, and political cartoons.

Description: create written, oral, and visual presentations of social studies information.

Description: use correct social studies terminology to explain historical concepts.

Description: use different forms of media to convey information, including written to visual and statistical to written or visual, using available computer software as appropriate.

Description: create thematic maps, graphs, and charts representing various aspects of the United States.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: pose and answer questions about geographic distributions and patterns shown on maps, graphs, charts, and available databases.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use a problem-solving process to identify a problem, gather information, list and consider options, consider advantages and disadvantages, choose and implement a solution, and evaluate the effectiveness of the solution.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: use a decision-making process to identify a situation that requires a decision, gather information, identify options, predict consequences, and take action to implement a decision.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: understand the contributions of the American Expeditionary Forces (AEF) led by General John J. Pershing.

Description: analyze the impact of significant technological innovations in World War I such as machine guns, airplanes, tanks, poison gas, and trench warfare that resulted in the stalemate on the Western Front.

Description: analyze major issues such as isolationism and neutrality raised by U.S. involvement in World War I, Woodrow Wilson's Fourteen Points, and the Treaty of Versailles.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze significant events such as the Battle of Argonne Forest.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: evaluate the impact of Progressive Era reforms, including initiative, referendum, recall, and the passage of the 16th, 17th, 18th, and 19th amendments.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: evaluate the impact of muckrakers and reform leaders such as Upton Sinclair, Susan B. Anthony, Ida B. Wells, and W. E. B. DuBois on American society.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: evaluate the impact of third parties, including the Populist and Progressive parties.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze causes and effects of events and social issues such as immigration, Social Darwinism, eugenics, race relations, nativism, the Red Scare, Prohibition, and the changing role of women.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze the impact of significant individuals such as Clarence Darrow, William Jennings Bryan, Henry Ford, Glenn Curtiss, Marcus Garvey, and Charles A. Lindbergh.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify reasons for U.S. involvement in World War II, including Italian, German, and Japanese dictatorships and their aggression, especially the attack on Pearl Harbor.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: evaluate the domestic and international leadership of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry Truman during World War II, including the U.S. relationship with its allies and domestic industry's rapid mobilization for the war effort.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze the function of the U.S. Office of War Information.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze major issues of World War II, including the Holocaust; the internment of German, Italian, and Japanese Americans and Executive Order 9066; and the development of conventional and atomic weapons.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze major military events of World War II, including the Battle of Midway, the U.S. military advancement through the Pacific Islands, the Bataan Death March, the invasion of Normandy, fighting the war on multiple fronts, and the liberation of concentration camps.

Description: evaluate the military contributions of leaders during World War II, including Omar Bradley, Dwight Eisenhower, Douglas MacArthur, Chester A. Nimitz, George Marshall, and George Patton.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the home front and how American patriotism inspired exceptional actions by citizens and military personnel, including high levels of military enlistment; volunteerism; the purchase of war bonds; Victory Gardens; the bravery and contributions of the Tuskegee Airmen, the Flying Tigers, and the Navajo Code Talkers; and opportunities and obstacles for women and ethnic minorities.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe U.S. responses to Soviet aggression after World War II, including the Truman Doctrine, the Marshall Plan, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the Berlin airlift, and John F. Kennedy's role in the Cuban Missile Crisis.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe how Cold War tensions were intensified by the arms race, the space race, McCarthyism, and the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC), the findings of which were confirmed by the Venona Papers.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain reasons and outcomes for U.S. involvement in the Korean War and its relationship to the containment policy.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain reasons and outcomes for U.S. involvement in foreign countries and their relationship to the Domino Theory, including the Vietnam War.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze the major issues and events of the Vietnam War such as the Tet Offensive, the escalation of forces, Vietnamization, and the fall of Saigon.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the responses to the Vietnam War such as the draft, the 26th Amendment, the role of the media, the credibility gap, the silent majority, and the anti-war movement.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: trace the historical development of the civil rights movement in the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries, including the 13th, 14th, 15th, and 19th amendments.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the roles of political organizations that promoted civil rights, including ones from African American, Chicano, American Indian, women's, and other civil rights movements.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify the roles of significant leaders who supported various rights movements, including Martin Luther King Jr., Cesar Chavez, Rosa Parks, Hector P. Garcia, and Betty Friedan.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: compare and contrast the approach taken by some civil rights groups such as the Black Panthers with the nonviolent approach of Martin Luther King Jr..
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: discuss the impact of the writings of Martin Luther King Jr. such as his "I Have a Dream" speech and "Letter from Birmingham Jail" on the civil rights movement.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe presidential actions and congressional votes to address minority rights in the United States, including desegregation of the armed forces, the Civil Rights acts of 1957 and 1964, and the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the role of individuals such as governors George Wallace, Orval Faubus, and Lester Maddox and groups, including the Congressional bloc of southern Democrats, that sought to maintain the status quo.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: evaluate changes and events in the United States that have resulted from the civil rights movement, including increased participation of minorities in the political process.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe how litigation such as the landmark cases of Brown v. Board of Education, Mendez v. Westminster, Hernandez v. Texas, Delgado v. Bastrop I.S.D., Edgewood I.S.D. v. Kirby, and Sweatt v. Painter played a role in protecting the rights of the minority during the civil rights movement.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify major causes and describe the major effects of the following events from 8000 BC to 500 BC: the development of agriculture and the development of the river valley civilizations.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify major causes and describe the major effects of the following events from 500 BC to AD 600: the development of the classical civilizations of Greece, Rome, Persia, India (Maurya and Gupta), China (Zhou, Qin, and Han), and the development of major world religions.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify major causes and describe the major effects of the following important turning points in world history from 600 to 1450: the spread of Christianity, the decline of Rome and the formation of medieval Europe; the development of Islamic caliphates and their impact on Asia, Africa, and Europe; the Mongol invasions and their impact on Europe, China, India, and Southwest Asia.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify major causes and describe the major effects of the following important turning points in world history from 1450 to 1750: the rise of the Ottoman Empire, the influence of the Ming dynasty on world trade, European exploration and the Columbian Exchange, European expansion, and the Renaissance and the Reformation.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify major causes and describe the major effects of the following important turning points in world history from 1750 to 1914: the Scientific Revolution, the Industrial Revolution and its impact on the development of modern economic systems, European imperialism, and the Enlightenment's impact on political revolutions.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify major causes and describe the major effects of the following important turning points in world history from 1914 to the present: the world wars and their impact on political, economic, and social systems; communist revolutions and their impact on the Cold War; independence movements; and globalization.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify the importance of imperialism, nationalism, militarism, and the alliance system in causing World War I.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify major characteristics of World War I, including total war, trench warfare, modern military technology, and high casualty rates.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the political impact of Woodrow Wilson's Fourteen Points and the political and economic impact of the Treaty of Versailles, including changes in boundaries and the mandate system.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify the causes of the February (March) and October revolutions of 1917 in Russia, their effects on the outcome of World War I, and the Bolshevik establishment of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: summarize the international, political, and economic causes of the global depression.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the responses of governments in the United States, Germany, and the Soviet Union to the global depression.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: describe the emergence and characteristics of totalitarianism.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the roles of various world leaders, including Benito Mussolini, Adolf Hitler, Hideki Tojo, Joseph Stalin, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Winston Churchill, prior to and during World War II.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the major causes and events of World War II, including the German invasions of Poland and the Soviet Union, the Holocaust, Japanese imperialism, the attack on Pearl Harbor, the Normandy landings, and the dropping of the atomic bombs.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: summarize how the outcome of World War II contributed to the development of the Cold War.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: summarize the factors that contributed to communism in China, including Mao Zedong's role in its rise, and how it differed from Soviet communism.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: identify the following major events of the Cold War, including the Korean War, the Vietnam War, and the arms race.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the roles of modern world leaders, including Ronald Reagan, Mikhail Gorbachev, Lech Walesa, and Pope John Paul II, in the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: summarize the rise of independence movements in Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia and reasons for ongoing conflicts.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain how Arab rejection of the State of Israel has led to ongoing conflict.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: summarize the development and impact of radical Islamic fundamentalism on events in the second half of the 20th century, including Palestinian terrorism and the growth of al Qaeda.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: explain the U.S. response to terrorism from September 11, 2001, to the present.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: create and interpret thematic maps, graphs, and charts to demonstrate the relationship between geography and the historical development of a region or nation.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: analyze and compare geographic distributions and patterns in world history shown on maps, graphs, charts, and models.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard

Description: locate places and regions of historical significance directly related to major eras and turning points in world history.
ContentStandard.Title: State Standard
